qas.question: What event led to the decline in wooden construction in New York City?
In the 19th century, New York city required water towers in the roofs of buildings that were more than how many stories tall?
What area was known for its garden apartments?
After the Great Fire of 1835, what became the most widespread building materials?
To prevent high water pressures at lower elevations what were built on many of the city's buildings?

context: <a3_0>Stone and brick<a3_0/> became the city's building materials of choice after the construction of wood-frame houses was limited in the aftermath of <a0_0>the Great Fire of 1835<a0_0/>. A distinctive feature of many of the city's buildings is the <a4_0>wooden roof-mounted water towers<a4_0/>. In the 1800s, the city required their installation on buildings higher than <a1_0>six<a1_0/> stories to prevent the need for excessively high water pressures at lower elevations, which could break municipal water pipes. Garden apartments became popular during the 1920s in outlying areas, such as <a2_0>Jackson Heights<a2_0/>.
